data.name: Mahjong II: Is this complex set a winning set?
data.description:
Mahjong is an ancient game in China, which spreads all over the world. But how can we check if a set of tiles is a winning set?

To simplify the question, we ignore the situation that it has chi-ed, pon-ed and kan-ed. (If you have finish the Kata named "Mahjong I", this Kata is an advanced version of it. In this Kata, there is not only one suit of the tiles.) You will get a string like "111m222p333s44455z" to describe a set of tiles. "m", "p" and "s" are 3 different suits including 9 tiles, but "z" is a suit only including 7. Your algorithm should return a boolean to tell if it's a winning set.

```ruby
winning_set?('111m222p333s44455z') #-> true
winning_set?('11123456789999m') #-> true
winning_set?('11223m5566p77788s') #-> false
```
tips:  
A set without chii, pon and kan will have exactly 14 tiles, and at most 4 of a kind.  
most of winning sets are like XXX-XXX-XXX-XXX-YY, in which XXX is ABC or AAA.  
111m222p333s44455z -> 111m-222p-333s-444z-55z  
11123456789999m -> 123m-456m-789m-999m-11m  
The suit 'z' doesn't have ABC. '123z' is invalid.  
A special set of tiles is AABBCCDDEEFFGG means seven pairs, like 1122m4455p667788s. there should not be any same pairs in it (Japanese Mahjong rules).  
Another special set of tiles is 19m19p19s1234567z and another tile in it, like 199m19p19s1234567z.
